instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01958: What is 820-01958? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.PP1V8_AWAKE: What is PP1V8_AWAKE? The PP1V8_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is indicative of a power rail that delivers 1.8 volts when the machine is in an "awake" state. This is not a traditional power state defined in the older Intel PCH documentation; it seems to be specific to newer MacBook architectures. The "awake" designation likely refers to a state where the MacBook is on and ready for user interaction, but it is not necessarily at full operational capacity (which would be denoted by an S0 state).
definitions.PP1V1_SLPS2R: What is PP1V1_SLPS2R? The PP1V1_SLPS2R power rail in the MacBook schematic provides a 1.1-volt supply in a specific low-power state indicated by the "_SLPS2R" suffix and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PP1V2_AWAKE: What is PP1V2_AWAKE? The PP1V2_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides 1.2 volts and is associated with the machine's awake state and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.PP0V9_SSD0: What is PP0V9_SSD0? This is a power rail for the soldered on SSD on newer Macbooks. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3: What is PPBUS_G3? This is a typo of PPBUS_G3H. When you see PPBUS_G3, assume they meant to type PPBUS_G3H.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no DFU
threads.message:
Hi, 
this Mac fall on the floor, no liquid spill. I have 20V 1,2A normally the Mac charge.
But no chime, no display. I can't put the Mac in DFU.
I measure 

<SIGNAL>PP1V2_AWAKE</SIGNAL> 1.2V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_AWAKE</SIGNAL> 1.8V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_AWAKE</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PPVDDCPU_AWAKE</SIGNAL> 0.755v
PPVDDCPUSRAM_AWAKE 0.802v
<SIGNAL>PP0V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> 0.800v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> 1.8v
<SIGNAL>PP1V25_SLPS2R_SMC_AVREF</SIGNAL> 1,2v
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> 1.1v
I try a mouse on the USB port and a externe HDD, no light.
can you help me please?
thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no DFU
threads.message:
Very likely broken solders, or traces.
Dropped machines are nightmare.

Do you get voltage on any big coil?
Check if starts disconnecting audio flex.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no DFU
threads.message:
OK i have nothing but no short on L9060, L7210, L7400, L7230, L7220, L8410, L8100.
Diode mode: L9060=0,355, L7210=0,135, L7400=0,158, L7230=0,135, L7220=0,135, L8410= 0,865, L8100=0,165.
I try without audio flex, same problem.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no DFU
threads.message:
G3S and SSD voltages come on?

Remove the board from shell and test it alone on the desk.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no DFU
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_G3S</SIGNAL> = 1,8V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL>=5V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3</SIGNAL>=12,6V
<SIGNAL>PP0V9_SSD0</SIGNAL>=0,9V
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL>=2,5V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_SSD0</SIGNAL> = 12,6V
With board remove of the top case, and alone on my desk.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no DFU
threads.message:
It should enter DFU.
If not, I can only suspect "broken solders, or traces", as first mentioned.
Probably waste of time...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no DFU
threads.message: no I can't enter in DFU, I don't waste more time, thanks
